ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture on some asynchronous days
Asynchronous "lectures" consisting of a slideshow with a recorded voice-over
Supersite, videos, documentaries, in addition to virtual seminar.
Combination of virtual seminar and prerecorded material
We studied through a combination of virtual seminars and asynchronous work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Subjunctive mood as well as correcting little grammatical errors from past years of classes

Honestly, I can't say that my Spanish improved much, if at all. Much of it was grammar review or basic vocabulary, which was certainly helpful, but there was not a lot of emphasis placed on actual conversational ability.

I learned Intermediate Spanish grammar, writing and speaking. I haven't taken Spanish in over 2 years, so I enjoyed and benefitted from the review at the beginning of the semester before delving into new content and more challenging grammar rules, texts and documentaries. However, that being said, this was a bit fast of a transition, especially from Elementary Spanish II.
Spanish
the past tense, subjunctive, and future tense
Expanded my Spanish vocabulary and ability to speak, read and understand the language.
I become more fluid in oral and written Spanish while developing an appreciation for different Spanish-speaking cultures through film and literature especially.
I minimally improved my knowledge and understanding of spanish.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
You had no choice but to be engaged which was helpful in the end 
There were a lot of assignments which felt very repetitive

Strengths: full immersion in the language with a professor to facilitate discussion whenever a student was stuck
Weaknesses: most of the work was completely unproductive busy work that I felt did not help me improve in my Spanish; course suffered due to online instruction; lack of emphasis on pronunciation (I highly recommend taking a section with a professor who is a native speaker!)

I liked how there were many different avenues of learning, we had reading assignments, listening activities, writing activities, but class lacked in speaking activities. I think this was due to the nature of Zoom classes. I would have liked more speaking activities that did not require letter graded weights. This would have allowed my classmates and I to engage and practice in a more relaxed way. I did not like how heavily structured the class was. This made class a bit robotic, and my speaking planned out in advance. I also did not like how heavy the course load was, even on days we had exams I would still spend 2-3 hours just working on Spanish.
Difficult to gain experience speaking the language virtually. Ample opportunities to practice grammar, however.
Strengths: good pacing of the material, helpful feedback and clear communication between the professor and students. Weaknesses: often large amount of homework assigned each week.
The balance between synchronous and asynchronous study was perfect. The pacing also worked well. However, it was a little difficult to coordinate group work outside of class.

I found this course to be very weak.  The instruction was minimally helpful and many of the assignments were on topics we had not covered in class. I think this class would benefit from a slightly slower pace, fewer assignments that are more in depth and less repetitive, and more comprehensive instruction. Overall, I found myself very disappointed with this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The videos for asynchronous days seemed a little unnecessary but the breakout room feature was good for making sure everyone participated

The class sorely missed interactive asynchronous content. After the first few weeks, there were no discussion posts and very few interactive assignments at all, so these days consisted mostly of watching slideshows that were not all too helpful, since they were obviously not interactive. I would have preferred more assignments that allowed us to work outside of class with our classmates. The few activities that incorporated this were very engaging and enjoyable.

I enjoyed the supersite learning activities and sometimes the activities where we had to work in groups on our own time to practice Spanish. This allowed for peer engagement and speaking practice which was nice, but I don't think it should have been a graded assignment. It added extra stress especially when the video assignments were due in in less than 2 days after the initial assignment day.  I would've liked if the purpose of this practice was solely for the instructor to comment and help students improve after watching the video, as a way to assess where everyone in the class is at for understanding a grammar rule/sentence construction as well as what should be reviewed.
Although this class is meant to be taken in-person, the professor greatly succeeded in making the virtual class experience excellent.

I appreciated the decision to use synchronous classes to introduce new information, discuss topics, or answer questions (and save worksheets for asynchronous classes). This was an excellent improvement over last year's Spanish class.

I disliked the asynchronous classes. I found them to not be engaging or conducive to learning. I also thought the Professor used breakout rooms too frequently during the seminars in lieu of instruction. Finally, assignments were frequently assigned prior to instruction on the topics they covered and were difficult to find. I found this course did not translate well to the virtual format and I was not engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Personally I would not just because there were other language option that seemed more interesting to me but I opted for this class so I could finish the language requirement sooner.

If you need to take the language credit, certainly. I would not recommend going out of your way to take this, though, as it is mostly a boring slog with instruction level equivalent to that of a high school course.

Take this class if you'd like to improve upon your basic elementary/Highschool Spanish as we learned a lot of grammar, listening and reading at the intermediate level, at a very fast paced. However, you will have to do ALOT of outside studying and practice on your own. Class on zoom is basically reviewing what you worked on / studied on your own. But sometimes it was really difficult to keep up with along with other classes etc. It's a lot of work but its rewarding. I think I learned a lot, despite the non-ideal nature of this language seminar class on a virtual platform. I didn't like how structured exams and assignments were though. This didn't really translate to helping my speaking, but I could read and listen better now.
I would recommend this course if one could take it with Prof. Seymour. She made learning and communicating in Spanish easy and engaging in a risk-free way.

I would not recommend this course. I found there to be an unnecessary amount of work and stress associated with a course in which I received little valuable instruction and failed to improve my Spanish. If students are able to skip this  course entirely or take it with a different professor, I would recommend that.
